answers.answer: HiThanks for writing to the forum!Your son could be suffering from Raynaud’s. A vascular surgeon should be consulted. Alternately he could be having peripheral neuropathy due to uncontrolled diabetes. You should run blood tests to rule out diabetes.It is difficult to comment beyond this at this stage. Maybe you can seek another opinion. Please let me know if there is any thing else and do keep me posted. Take care!

question: My Son has Raynaud's he is now 12, it has gotten worse.  I first went to my doctor with concerns when he was about 3 years old.  He only gets it in his feet. The same two toes on both feet with patches would go white.  It would take 15 minutes of rubbing them to get the circulation back.  He would get this several times a week during the winter and occasionally during the summer even when no signs of coldness.   As years have gone and continue reassurance from the doctor he is fine it's Raynaud's, that happens, and  seeing the severity of this going from not just two toes and some spotches to both feet totally white and numb to almost daily even outside in July.  I made an appointment asking for tests and help.  He had a Duplex Arterial Ulterasound of the lower extremities.  The doctor called back said everything was fine.  I tried to leave it, finely I went and got a copy of the report to assure myself.   The report said the ankle-brachial index is essentially normal bilaterally.  But, also stated that this test is to show Large vessel disease and Raynauds is a small vessel disease and the word essentially did not sit well also. I do not know if I am still worring for nothing.  Should I requesta  certain test and what one's? If I need to ignore the primary doctor and seek a specialist and what kind?
title: Juvenile Raynaulds in Boys
